name: Selárlaug - Remote Donation Pool in Vopnafjörður
description: Selárlaug represents one of Iceland's most charmingly remote and trust-based swimming facilities, operating without regular staffing on an honor-system donation basis where visitors deposit payment in a wall-mounted box and enjoy an intimate geothermal pool heated by natural spring waters in a beautiful riverside setting that epitomizes the peaceful isolation and natural beauty of East Iceland's northeastern corner. Located 3.5 kilometers off Route 85 on the road toward Bakkafjörður and 12 kilometers from Vopnafjörður town center, the pool occupies a tranquil spot on the banks of the Selá river in a landscape of rolling hills, distant mountains, and the windswept coastal terrain characteristic of this sparsely populated region where sheep outnumber people and isolation remains a defining characteristic despite modern roads. Vopnafjörður is a small fishing community of approximately 700 residents tucked at the head of a long, narrow fjord on Iceland's northeastern coast—one of the country's most remote municipalities where tourism infrastructure remains minimal and authentic rural Icelandic life continues largely unchanged by the visitor influx affecting more accessible regions. Selárlaug's unstaffed operation reflects both Icelandic culture's high trust levels (vandalism and theft remain rare, and most visitors honestly deposit donations) and practical realities of maintaining a facility in a location where full-time staffing would be economically impossible given limited local population and visitor numbers.
